title: Beacon Dr. helps Highlands volleyball player return
text:
Beacon Dr. helps Highlands volleyball player return 
Updated: Tue, Oct 06 2015, 03:10 PM 
CINCINNATI (Richard Skinner) -- Dr. Glen McClung had undergone several surgeries for his own sports injuries over the years, so he knew not only the physical anguish that Highlands High School's Anna Marie Houliston faced when she came to see him last November, but also the mental anguish of not knowing if she would get to play her senior season of volleyball. 
Houliston said she remembered exactly what Dr. McClung, who is a physician with Beacon Orthopaedics and Sports Medicine, told her and her parents upon their initial visit. 
"He said, 'I can tell how much she wants to get back out there and I will do everything to help see that she does,'" said Houliston. "I was really nervous about it, because I didn't want to miss my senior season. There are seven seniors on our team who have been together for seven years and this year is what makes it all count." 
Houliston, who was selected Northern Kentucky Coaches Association Division II honorable mention all-star last season, underwent surgery for a torn labrum in her hip a few weeks after that initial visit, and after extensive therapy was able to return in time for the start of the regular season, which has two weeks left until postseason play begins. 
McClung says he understands how important it is for high school athletes to be able to return as quickly as possible, because there are no redshirt years and playing at that age can mean so much. 
"There's just such a limited amount of time for them to compete and they have put so much into it in both time and effort," said McClung, who said he had Tommy John surgery and two arthroscopic knee surgeries from injuries playing football and wrestling while in military school. "It's not only an athletic endeavor for them, but it's also a huge social structure and outlet for them, as well. My job when they have an injury is get them in the day of or the next day, get them diagnosed, worked up and back on the road to recovery. This such a huge ordeal. It affects the whole family. It's such a difficult time for these kids." 
Houliston said her hip began hurting when she was in the eighth grade and the pain got progressively worse as she played not only in high school, but also for a competitive club team. It finally got to the point, she said, where it hurt to even sit down, but she was determined to finish her junior season before getting it looked at. 
According to McClung, it can often be difficult to diagnose the severity of a hip injury and that rehabbing it is often the first attempt at fixing it. 
"Hip pathology can be elusive," he said. "Many times injuries like this can go undetected. We were able to diagnose her right off the bat with a labral tear." 
Houliston couldn't put any weight on the hip for the first six weeks after the surgery and attended Highlands' state championship football game in December in Bowling Green with the aid of crutches. Even using crutches was an initial ordeal for her. 
"The first day I was using them, I slipped on a wet floor and fell on my hip," she said. "It freaked me out, but I got back up and realized I was going to be okay." 
Three months after the surgery she was able to use just one crutch and put a little more weight on the hip and finally got to begin rehabbing it in April. 
The surgery and rehab prevented her from playing club volleyball. 
"That was hard, because I hate missing games, but I knew I had to do everything in rehab to play this season," she said. 
All the hard work in rehab paid off when she returned by the time the season started in early August. Returning for her senior season meant even more, because she doesn't plan to play in college. 
"It means everything to make it back for this one last year," she said. "I look back and there were a lot of times during rehab where I thought, 'I can't do this anymore.' Wanting to play one more year was the thing that motivated me." 
Seeing athletes like Houliston return is what motivates McClung as well. 
"It's the whole reason I entered the career I'm in," he said. "That's what makes it all worth it - to get them back to a competitive level and playing the sport they love. For me, it means everything."
